Touring Philadelphia with community business owners. 

Shortly, I will speak about protests across Pennsylvania and condemn racism, oppression, and injustice.
name: Tom Wolf

text:
Socially distanced greetings with 
@PhillyPolice
 Chief Danielle Outlaw.
 
Chief Outlaw has spoken out to condemn the death of George Floyd. She reported that this weekend's protests were peaceful —  the criminal activity we saw was not a part of protests, according to police.
name: Tom Wolf

text:
In Philadelphia today to talk about how we can support the black community during this difficult time.

First stop: Meeting with 
@PhillyMayor
 & 
@PhillyPolice
. 

We know people are hurting. We must move toward ending racism and promoting healing while keeping Pennsylvanians safe.
name: Tom Wolf
Tom Wolf

text:
I don't want to lose sight of why we are here.

I want to again send my condolences to the family and friends of George Floyd, and everyone impacted by oppression, racism, and violence.

Every day, in every corner of our society, we need to work at eliminating racism.
name: Tom Wolf

text:
I urge everyone to be peaceful.

I urge everyone to have respect for our communities and our neighbors.

And I urge all of us to continue to call out injustice.

And I thank all of our first responders.
name: Tom Wolf

text:
Many Pennsylvanians joined together yesterday to speak out against injustice and made their voices heard peacefully.

But in some of our cities – including Philadelphia, Harrisburg, and Pittsburgh – people took advantage of these peaceful protests to incite violence and looting.
name: Tom Wolf

text:
Today, many will gather to protest the murder of George Floyd.

They will also call attention to the crying need for all of us to rededicate ourselves to the commonwealth we deserve.

One that is decent, equal, and fair to all.
name: Tom Wolf

text: This declaration authorizes the commonwealth and its agencies to assist municipalities in their response to de-escalate violence and keep our communities safe: http://governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-signs-emergency-declaration-to-assist-municipalities-during-protests/…
name: Tom Wolf

text: This evening, I signed a disaster emergency declaration using my authority to provide all necessary assistance to municipalities as they respond to the escalation of protests in Harrisburg, Philadelphia, and Pittsburgh.
name: Tom Wolf

text: People have every right to speak out and demonstrate, but it’s unacceptable to take advantage of protests to incite violence, harm others, and destroy property.
name: Tom Wolf

text:
Today I signed sweeping police reform into law, including measures to:
Ban no-knock warrants
Limit use of neck restraints
Empower civilian review boards

These laws build trust between police and the people they serve, while keeping Virginians safe.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
I just signed new laws that make meaningful reform to policing and our criminal justice system by:
increasing penalties for false police reports based on a person's race, gender identity, or disability
requiring judges to dismiss charges when the prosecution and defense agree
name: Ralph Northam

text: It is with the deepest sadness that Pam and I mourn the passing of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. A brilliant legal mind and an unwavering beacon in the fight for equal justice, her loss leaves a tremendous void on the Supreme Court and in our country. May her memory be a blessing.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
In America, we believe in second chances—and as the General Assembly considers criminal justice reforms, our administration is continuing our work to give those who have paid their debts to society a second chance.

As of today, we have restored civil rights to 36,242 Virginians.
name: Ralph Northam
Ralph Northam

text: I look forward to continuing discussions with lawmakers—now and in advance of next session—as we increase police accountability, transparency, and community engagement.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
This session is an opportunity to take long overdue action on police reform. 

My top priorities include standardizing mandatory training requirements (including on use of force), empowering civilian review boards, and making it easier to de-certify bad officers.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
The world has lost a giant in John Lewis. His moral courage, his lifelong fight for justice, and his decades of public service have made our nation, and all of us, better. 

Let’s honor his memory by carrying on his life’s work — not just with words, but with action.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
On #July4th, we celebrate the birth of our nation—and the promise of freedom and equality that this country and Commonwealth were founded upon.

Today, and every day, we must strive to live up to these ideals, and continue the pursuit of liberty, justice, and opportunity for all.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
On #Juneteenth, we commemorate the day in 1865 when the last enslaved people in America learned of the Emancipation Proclamation, a pivotal step toward freedom and justice for all.

As we celebrate, we must also educate––on how far we have come, and how far we have to go.
name: Ralph Northam
Ralph Northam

text:
53 years ago, the Supreme Court unanimously struck down laws banning interracial marriage in Virginia and 15 other states.

Today, we celebrate the love and legacy of Mildred and Richard Loving––may their courage inspire us on the march toward racial justice. #LovingDay
name: Ralph Northam

text:
Over the next few weeks, I will continue to meet with activists, victims of violence, policymakers, members of stakeholder boards and organizations, and law enforcement officials.

We are taking action.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
Today, we remember the brave forces who stormed the beaches at Normandy, risking everything to defeat fascism. 

As the world honors their sacrifice on this 76th anniversary of #DDay, may their example inspire us to unite in the cause of freedom and justice for all.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
The legacy of racism continues not just in isolated incidents like we saw in Minneapolis a few days ago.

And the legacy of racism continues as part of a system that touches every person and every aspect of our lives, whether we know it or not.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
I know these actions will not bring back the lives lost. 

But they will help us create the systematic change that is needed to make sure that what happened to George Floyd, and Breonna Taylor, and Ahmaud Arbery––and so many other black Americans––doesn't continue to happen.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
Communities of color are calling out for racial justice and healing––we have to keep listening to and learning from them.

We have to keep working to ensure our law enforcement officers have the training, and exercise the judgment to do the right thing.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
I hear you, and I am here to work with you––that is my message to protestors in Richmond and around Virginia.

I cannot know the depth of the pain that black Americans feel right now. 

But I can stand with you, I can support you, and together we can turn this pain into action.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
As Governor of Virginia, I call on all Virginians to join together and build a renewed commitment to working for justice and fair treatment.

Read my full statement here:
name: Ralph Northam

text: We have all seen too many people harassed, abused, and killed by law enforcement officers, in too many places, for too long—just for being black. I also know that others are exploiting this pain and are now causing violence.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
I acknowledge each of the voices crying out for justice and healing across the United States and in our Commonwealth. I affirm the deep concerns from the black community.

I hear you. I know your pain is real.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
This is our shared responsibility—this is a humanity issue.

People are crying out for justice and healing. But those aren’t feelings—they’re actions, and we have a lot of work to do in this country and in our Commonwealth.
name: Ralph Northam

text:
This has been such a sad and emotional week, with too many violent and blatant reminders of how far our country is from genuine equity and fair treatment.

George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery, and many others have been wrongfully killed, simply for being black.
name: Ralph Northam

text: Justice Ginsberg was a stalwart public servant who spent her life working to hold our country accountable for our promises of equity, equality, truth, and justice. What a devastating loss.
name: Tony Evers

text: As I have said before, it’s on all of us to start the hard but just work of dismantling racism in our communities and state. I’m proud of our young people who are leading the way.
name: Tony Evers

text: We have much work to do, from repairing the physical damage and the divisions that caused so much fear, pain, and devastation, to addressing the critical issues of equity and justice in our communities and state. We’re ready to get to work, together.
name: Tony Evers

text:
"It is imperative for the Wisconsin State Legislature to reconvene after months of inaction and take up meaningful measures to address issues of police accountability, brutality, and criminal justice reform."

I couldn’t agree more. Thank you, 
@Bucks
.
name: Tony Evers

text: We cannot let the hateful actions of a few designed to create chaos distract us from our pursuit for a more fair, equitable, and accountable state and country for Jacob Blake and the many others who deserve justice.
name: Tony Evers

text: We must turn from violence and remember that any single act of injustice against one person is less justice for us all.
name: Tony Evers

text: I also ask the individuals who are not there to exercise those rights to please stay home and let local first responders, law enforcement, and members of the Wisconsin National Guard do their jobs.
name: Tony Evers

text: Tonight, and in the days ahead, if you are going to protest, please do so peacefully and safely. Please do not allow the actions of a few distract us from the work we must do together to demand justice, equity, and accountability.
name: Tony Evers

text: We cannot allow the cycle of systemic racism and injustice to continue. We also cannot continue going down this path of damage and destruction.
name: Tony Evers

text: But as I said yesterday, and as I’ll reiterate today, everyone should be able to exercise their fundamental right—whether a protester or member of the press—peacefully and safely.
name: Tony Evers

text: We cannot forget the reason why these protests began, and what we have seen play out over the last two nights and many nights this year is the pain, anguish, and exhaustion of being Black in our state and country.
name: Tony Evers

text: The ability to exercise First Amendment rights is a critically important part of our democracy and the pursuit of justice. But there remains a line between peaceful assembly and what we saw last night that put individuals, families, and businesses in danger.
name: Tony Evers

text:
We must rise to this movement and this moment and meet it with our empathy, our humanity, and a fierce commitment to disrupt the cycle of systemic racism and bias that devastates Black families and communities. 
 
ICYMI today's press conference is here
name: Tony Evers

text: So, today, we announced a Special Session of the Legislature to convene at noon on August 31st, to take up this package of legislation and begin the long but important path toward ensuring our state and our country start to live up to our promises of equity and justice.
name: Tony Evers

text: This includes investing in community violence interruption programs, addressing inappropriate use of force, and prohibiting dangerous police practices, among many other needed reforms and accountability measures.
name: Tony Evers

text: I have said all along that although we must offer our empathy, equally important is our action. In the coming days, we will demand just that of elected officials in our state who have failed to recognize the racism in our state and our country for far too long.
name: Tony Evers

text: We stand with all those who have and continue to demand justice, equity, and accountability for Black lives in our country—lives like those of George Floyd, of Breonna Taylor, Tony Robinson, Dontre Hamilton, Ernest Lacy, and Sylville Smith.
name: Tony Evers

text: While we do not have all of the details yet, what we know for certain is that he is not the first Black man or person to have been shot or injured or mercilessly killed at the hands of individuals in law enforcement in our state or our country.
name: Tony Evers

text: Today I pardoned 18 individuals-the largest group since re-establishing the Pardon Advisory Board. While a pardon won’t fix the challenges facing our criminal justice system, it can have a tremendous impact on a person’s life. More on today’s pardons here:
name: Tony Evers

text: We are prepared to activate the Wisconsin National Guard to protect state buildings and infrastructure and are continuing to work with local law enforcement to understand their response to last night’s events and their plan to respond to similar events in the future.
name: Tony Evers

text: We also cannot allow ourselves to forget the reason why these protests began: because of the murder of George Floyd, of Breonna Taylor, of the many Black lives taken before them, and because racism and structural inequality still pervade this country.
name: Tony Evers
Tony Evers

text: I want to be clear: violence against any person—whether in the middle of the street in broad daylight, at home trying to sleep, going for a run, or happening upon a protest as was the case last night—is wrong. It should never be tolerated.
name: Tony Evers

text: What happened in Madison last night presented a stark contrast from the peaceful protests we have seen across our state in recent weeks, including significant damage to state property.
name: Tony Evers

text: This legislation can only be a first step because we know the solution to racism and the racial disparities Wisconsin faces can’t be solved with any single bill or package of bills, or person—it’s on all of us, together. This can only be the beginning.
name: Tony Evers

text: Our country promises the opportunity of justice and equity and in the wake of the murders of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor and the calls for justice across our state and nation, and as we celebrate Juneteenth today, we are called to deliver on that promise.
name: Tony Evers

text: I want to thank the peaceful protesters who continue to make their voices heard around the state for keeping this conversation going and demanding change. This is a watershed moment for our state and nation and inaction is not an option.
name: Tony Evers

text: Today would have been Breonna Taylor’s 27th birthday. As we reflect today on Breonna’s life, we must also reflect on the systemic change needed to address the disease of racism in our state and our country. Her life mattered and her family deserves justice. #SayHerName
name: Tony Evers

text: Join me in honoring the life of George Floyd today at 2:45 CT with 8 minutes and 46 seconds of silence to reflect on his life and on the work we have to do to build equitable and just communities.
name: Tony Evers

text: We must confront society’s comfort with racism. We must be willing to face it, with clear eyes and open hearts, recognizing that folks who look like me have been part of creating, exacerbating, and benefiting from the systems that we must now turn to dismantle.
name: Tony Evers

text: This legislation is an important first step, but we know the solution to racism isn’t in one bill or one person. We need systemic change to address the racism in our state and our country.
name: Tony Evers

text: We can start with accountability for unacceptable use of force by certain law enforcement officers in our country and our state. I am calling on the Legislature to immediately pass Assembly Bill 1012 that would reform use of force policies and send it to my desk for signature.
name: Tony Evers

text: There was no empathy or humanity in George Floyd’s death, but there must be empathy and humanity in our response to it. We must offer our compassion, we must offer our support, but most of all, we must offer our action.
name: Tony Evers

text: We need systemic change to address the racism in our state and our country. As folks continue to protest and demand accountability and change, please do so peacefully—be kind to each other, help each other, and keep each other safe.
name: Tony Evers

text: Right now, we must respond with our empathy and compassion. We must remember that anger and grief about injustice never need justification.
name: Tony Evers

text: We cannot let the work of a few undermine the pain felt by our Black neighbors or distract from the source of this grief and anger—we must remember George Floyd, his life matters, he should still be alive today.
name: Tony Evers

text: The solution isn’t in one person, it’s in all of us, together. We must confront our comfortability with racism. We must reestablish trust with communities of color. We must be willing to listen, we must be willing to be uncomfortable, we must be willing to do the work.
name: Tony Evers

text: This was not an anomaly. We hear the echo of the words of Eric Garner. We relive the pain of the death of Black Wisconsinites like Dontre Hamilton, Ernest Lacy, and Sylville Smith. Frustration and anger about systemic injustices are always justified.
name: Tony Evers

text: Earlier this week, another Black life was extinguished before our eyes. His name was George Floyd. He was 46. His life matters and his family deserves justice. There was no empathy or humanity in his death.
name: Tony Evers

Gary Herbert

(2/4)

@andersonljess

text: Utah offers its deepest condolences to the family of Officer Lyday and the Ogden community. I am grateful for his heroism, love, and service. Now more than ever, we need law enforcement like Nathan; capable of empathy, courage, and understanding as they do their difficult jobs.
name: Gary Herbert

text: Overwhelmed and grateful to meet with people who helped care for and clean the people’s house after last night’s protests. People are stepping up right and left - cleaning in the hot sun, offering cool water, and dropping off pizza.
name: Gary Herbert

text: We were deeply saddened to see the defacement of our beautiful Capitol building by this weekend’s protesters. We are heartened by the many individuals wanting to help clean its stone walls and grounds.
name: Gary Herbert

text: We are in close contact with our department of public safety and receiving regular updates. Our hearts break for the family of George Floyd and for his unnecessary death.
name: Gary Herbert
Eric Holcomb

name: Eric Holcomb

text: As I stated yesterday, injuring the innocent in response to an injustice is counterproductive. I’ve asked the Indiana State Police to fully support and make resources available to local communities across our state to ensure our citizens and their property remain safe. 2/3
name: Eric Holcomb

text:
Along with many Washingtonians, I am heartbroken over the death of Breonna Taylor. 

We’re going to do our part in Washington state to make sure our justice system is transparent and equitable, as it should be everywhere. 

We have to prevent tragedies like this from happening.
name: Jay Inslee

text: But we cannot rely on McConnell to have the integrity nor the courage to protect our democracy from Trump’s worst impulses. Are there enough Republicans in the Senate who still care about justice to block another Trump appointment? The voice of the American people will be heard.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
In this moment of addressing historic inequities, we cannot turn to violence. More violence and chaos is never the solution. 

We all have a responsibility to contribute to the path to peace and justice - not push us further from it.
name: Jay Inslee

text: Martin Luther King Jr. said “the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.” We can’t rest on our laurels - we need to help bend it. It will take all of us.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
On this day in 1963, the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom pushed our country to address the deep injustices of racism.

57 years later, that message is just as relevant and needed more than ever.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
Federal officers have left WA, confirmed by 
@DHSgov
. 

That means Washingtonians no longer have to worry about the White House's aim to provoke confrontation and undermine peaceful protests.
name: Jay Inslee

text: Such a one as John is a rare thing for anyone to have had the honor to know. Just to be in his presence made all of us in the House more mindful of the need for justice & our ability to render it. We are all rich who can say, "I served with John Lewis.”
name: Jay Inslee

text:
Trudi and I join Washingtonians in mourning the loss of one of Bothell's police officers.

I send my deepest condolences to the family and friends of this public servant killed serving their community.
name: Jay Inslee

text: I'm deeply disappointed and totally reject the language of my cousin Mike Brown who made inflammatory comments about recent protests. The language is unacceptable and just flat wrong, particularly from a law enforcement officer, as we try to heal the divisions of our community.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
The Civil Rights Act was a huge legislative step toward  justice, but the injustices of discrimination run deep in our country. 

It is time to take another big step and deliver on the promises we made as a nation 56 years ago today.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
The Justice in Policing Act takes crucial, substantive steps toward racial justice in law enforcement. I commend the House for their decisive action. 

We're committed to working with legislators and community members to take critical actions like these at the state level, too.
name: Jay Inslee

Our new task force will recommend actions we can take to create a more just WA. It includes community leaders, impacted family members and law enforcement representatives.
name: Jay Inslee

. She is passionate about entrepreneurship, helping others meet their financial goals and advocating for equity and justice. 

Without #DACA, should would not be able to achieve her dream of owning her own business.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
Interracial marriage bans ended 53 years ago. And it was only because Mildred and Richard Loving, and thousands of others, had the courage to fight against racial injustice.

That fight lives on in those demanding justice for Black lives today. #LovingDay
name: Jay Inslee

text: This is a challenging time. Many in our state are expressing heartfelt outrage at the very real racial injustices in our society. We have work to do now and in the future to both advance equity and protect the gains we’ve made.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
I have become convinced the Pierce County Sheriff should not complete the investigation of the death of Manuel Ellis. 

There will be a new investigation and charging decision made independent of Pierce County law enforcement. 1/5
name: Jay Inslee

text:
We cannot undo systemic racism overnight. But we can and must do more to ensure just, humane treatment by police.

A start:
 independent misconduct investigations/prosecutions
 restricting chokeholds and other use of force
 holding officers accountable for one another
name: Jay Inslee

text: We all want these cases to end. But until then, when these stories become part of the bitter history of racism in this country, we must make sure that each and every case is given the highest level of scrutiny. 5/5
name: Jay Inslee

text: I will continue this work so the community and I can present lawmakers with legislation that should include independent investigations, requiring police to intervene/report unlawful use of force by another officer and examining the use of force—including restraint techniques. 4/5

text: My staff and I have met in recent days with activists, protest leaders, families of victims of police killings, law enforcement officials and experts to begin the work of creating a permanent process to give independent review to these cases. 3/5

text: Manuel Ellis was one of far, far too many Black men who died in police custody in America. Washingtonians deserve every assurance investigations and charging decisions related deaths of people in police custody are handled with urgency, independence and commitment to justice. 2/5

text:
These are the rantings of an insecure man trying to look strong, after building his entire political career on racism and the lie of birtherism. He is — again — failing to address the underlying injustices facing black Americans.

It is not leadership.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
We cannot - and will not - allow those who wanted to create destruction to suppress or obscure the legitimate protests going on. 

We know racism’s roots run deep in America. Every single one of us has work to do to dig them out. 

We’re committed to that work in Washington.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
Today I activated 200 additional members of the WA National Guard. I have complete faith that downtown Seattle will recover from this quickly and the state will help, however we can.

But we won’t allow vandalism and destruction to obscure the protest's central call for justice.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
Saturday’s disheartening events in Seattle – carried out by a smattering of the thousands of protesters on hand – will not deter the cause of justice. 

Hundreds of public servants and volunteers are already helping clean up the property damage done.
name: Jay Inslee

text: If you choose to protest today, please be safe and peaceful. These are important issues that deserve our full attention, without distraction from violence and destruction. Without solutions to inequity, the long road to justice will run even longer.
name: Jay Inslee

text: Together, we grieve for the death of George Floyd, and many, many others. The events in Minnesota and across the nation the past few nights have been stunning and illustrate how inequity causes people to lose faith in their public institutions.
name: Jay Inslee

text: As people gather today to protest the unjust death of George Floyd, I hope they do so peacefully and safely. Everyone has the freedom - and the right - to demonstrate and speak their mind. However, violence and destruction have no place in Washington state or our country.
name: Jay Inslee

text:
It is imperative on all of us, especially those in positions to impact the lives of the people we serve, to continue pushing for justice across America. 

We have made progress in Washington state, but our march toward equality is far from over.
name: Jay Inslee

text: To law enforcement already serving us in South Dakota, thank you! We support you, and we will continue to stand with you each and every day. South Dakota will also continue to respect the key principles that make America special, even if other cities and states won’t. (13/13)

text: It doesn’t have to be this way. In South Dakota, we salute law enforcement for their hard work to keep our communities safe and strong. While other states and cities are demonizing police officers, we’re forging a different path. (7/)

text:

 and I have announced plans for meaningful law enforcement reform in #Ohio.

text: Through these principles, we will address the structural flaws of a criminal justice system that has demonstrated itself to be too expensive, too punitive, and too ineffective at keeping ALL families safe.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Today, I’m announcing seven principles to build a more equitable criminal justice system in our state – which for too long has disproportionately pursued and punished people of color. You can read them here: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22181…
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Peaceful expression of anger is a powerful, longstanding tradition in this nation, and I am committed to ensuring that Illinois residents’ right to protest are protected. I will continue to fight for justice and equity today and every day going forward.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: I don’t pretend to know the pain experienced by Black Americans. But I do know that the circumstances surrounding Breonna Taylor’s death brings an overwhelming sense of rage, of passion, of sorrow to so many – including me.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Today, a grand jury made a decision that doesn’t capture the injustice of what we know to have happened to Breonna Taylor. The grand jury’s lesser charge of a single officer does not address the loss of her life. This is, to put it simply, a gross miscarriage of justice.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Governor Pritzker joins Mayor Lightfoot, Cook County Board President Preckwinkle and community leaders to discuss the Breonna Taylor decision.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: As we honor Justice Ginsburg’s extraordinary legacy and accomplishments, let us continue to fight for the ideals she stood for: Equality, justice, and women’s rights.
name: J. B. Pritzker
J. B. Pritzker

text: Despite the fact that this is a national program that was poorly designed & susceptible to fraud, I can promise Illinoisans that our state government & law enforcement authorities will do everything in our power to support anyone who has been affected by this nationwide failure.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
2) What is Illinois doing?

Because this scheme is nationwide, we’re fully cooperating with federal investigators. 
@IllinoisIDES
 is working with law enforcement and taking every action to track down & cut off fraudulent claims, reviewing flagged files to identify patterns.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Our current criminal justice system is too punitive and too ineffective at fulfilling its purpose: keeping Illinois families safe. That means all our families, no matter where they live, no matter what their income level is, no matter the color of their skin.
name: J. B. Pritzker
J. B. Pritzker

text: This investment has equity at its core. I want to especially commend the Careers with Conscious program & the specific opportunities for mentorship dedicated to young Black Peorians. To be a city and a state that truly advances justice, we've to put our money where our mouth is.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
Five years ago, the Supreme Court made marriage equality the law of the land.

As someone who worked to pass it here in Illinois, I know that our work isn't finished until we secure full equality and justice for every American.

Happy #PrideMonth, everyone!
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
Yesterday, we marched. 

Today, we keep fighting for true justice for our Black neighbors across our state and nation.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Through protest and policy, we will build an Illinois full of justice, equity and opportunity for all of our people.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: I'm working with the General Assembly on genuine criminal justice reform, a fundamentally reimagined version of policing, sustained investment in Black communities and commemorating Juneteenth as an official state holiday for years to come.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
As we celebrate #Juneteenth, our work to secure justice for Black Americans must continue because we've not yet become the nation that we aspire to be. 

Read my Juneteenth proclamation here: https://www2.illinois.gov/IISNews/21706-Juneteenth_2020_Proclamation.pdf…
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
"We cannot face this moment without reckoning with the systemic racism that got us here."

Moving forward requires us to address the root of the problem: systemic racism that must be dismantled at every level. Thank you for your powerful words, 
@SAKimFoxx
.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
I had a roundtable in Springfield today with local leaders and three teenage organizers of the recent Black Lives Matter march: Allaijah Davis, Ariona Fairlee and Nykeyla Henderson.

Your leadership at such a young age is inspiring, and I believe it will lead to real change.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
George Floyd deserved to breathe and to live. 

As he is laid to rest today, join me and 
@LtGovStratton
 in honoring him and countless others who've suffered these vile, horrid acts.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
I’m marching with activists, advocates and elected leaders in the Southland and calling for justice. 

Justice for George Floyd, Ahmad Arbery, Breonna Taylor and the countless others who died when there was no camera there. 

We’re here because their deaths cannot be in vain.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: We need to truly address the injustice and disinvestment in Black communities and in Black families.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
We're coming together today at the South Suburban Day of Action to demand justice. 

I am here to pledge my support for the Black Caucus and for the solutions that come from the community. 

Because Black Lives Matter.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
I've met a lot of people in my role as governor, but it's the youngest Illinoisans who have inspired me the most.

Autumn Cain, Mariah Cooley and Sincere Williams organized a march attended by hundreds in Peoria to demand justice for George Floyd.

I'm so proud of you—keep it up!
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Breonna Taylor would have turned 27 today. Her future was stolen from her, and we must honor her and the countless other victims of racist violence by making real, meaningful change in our country. We cannot rest until justice is truly served.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
We need justice in this state. 

There is no justice without police accountability, without criminal justice reform, and without real investment in Black communities.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Todos los sitios del estado ahora ofrecen a cualquiera una prueba gratis de #covid19, a pesar de los síntomas. No se requiere cita, referencia médica o seguro. Si recientemente atendio protestas, hágase la prueba - cinco días después de atender o inmediatamente si tiene síntomas.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text:
I do not pretend to know the pain that’s experienced by Black America. 

As we look for a way forward and to reform our laws and justice system, the leadership here and across the state is so important.

Community activism and peaceful organizing and faith must help show the way.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: As we live through exceedingly difficult times, we must recognize our shared humanity, unite against all forms of hate and show empathy and compassion for one another — especially as we fight for full equality & justice for every American, no matter your color, creed or identity.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: This investigation requires all possible accountability and transparency to deliver the closest thing to justice here – but it will never bring George Floyd back.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: We must actually do something to change that reality – to make it so men like George Floyd are not killed on a street corner, gasping for air in broad daylight – one moment alive, and the next moment, gone.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Events that echo what we have seen happen to too many people, too many times, in too many places – and yet we, as a people, have not yet found the humanity to stop these vile, horrid acts from happening, to truly contend with the racism that permeates our society and root it out.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: I feel compelled to use this platform to address what happened to George Floyd in Minneapolis – and to Breonna Taylor in Kentucky, and Ahmaud Arbery in Georgia, and Christian Cooper in New York City, and countless others whose memories we cannot allow time to erase.
name: J. B. Pritzker

text: Thank you to Zio’s in Omaha for honoring our law enforcement officers who sacrifice so much to protect our communities! #SupportBlue
name: Pete Ricketts

text: Susanne and I are keeping the officer that was shot today in our thoughts and prayers. May God be with him and his family during this horribly difficult time. Today’s events are a reminder of the selfless service and sacrifice of law enforcement in our communities.
name: Pete Ricketts

text:
For far too long, Senator Chambers’ hateful rhetoric has gone unchecked. I condemn Ernie’s sexist slurs against women and his disgraceful remarks towards law enforcement.

Full statement:
name: Pete Ricketts

text: "A Nebraska Jesuit university apologized Friday on behalf of a professor who tweeted that a pro-police rally in Omaha ought to be retitled a 'white supremacist rally.'"
name: Pete Ricketts

text: Juneteenth is the oldest known celebration of the ending of slavery in the United States and it is a celebration of freedom, justice, and equality for all Americans. #HappyJuneteenth2020
name: Pete Ricketts

text: Out of respect for George Floyd’s memorial service in Minneapolis at 1:00pm CT, my office will not be hosting English or Spanish press briefings this afternoon. Next week’s press briefing schedule will be announced at a later time.
name: Pete Ricketts

text: I condemn the destruction of property in both Lincoln and Omaha.  This distracts from the memory of George Floyd and the grief and anguish being expressed in the wake of his death.
name: Pete Ricketts

text: Thank you to the significant majority of protestors who were peaceful last night.  Peaceful protest is the right way to exercise our First Amendment rights.  Thank you to the law enforcement who professionally managed the protest.
name: Pete Ricketts

text: I have seen the video of former Officer Chauvin killing George Floyd, and I am appalled and angry.  Events like this break the trust between law enforcement and communities of color.  Justice must be served.
name: Pete Ricketts

text: WATCH: Gov. Ricketts provides an update on Test Nebraska, proclaims #NationalPoliceWeek to honor Nebraska's law enforcement officers.
name: Pete Ricketts

text: As Americans, we have a right to peacefully assemble but engaging in mob violence will not be tolerated in the state of Florida. I look forward to working with the Legislature next session to sign a new proposal into law that protects our citizens and law enforcement officers.
name: Ron DeSantis
Ron DeSantis

text: Today I announced bold legislation that creates new criminal offenses and increases penalties for those who target law enforcement and participate in violent or disorderly assemblies. We will always stand with our men and women in uniform who keep our communities safe.
name: Ron DeSantis
Ron DeSantis
Ron DeSantis

text:
Florida has zero tolerance for violence, rioting & looting. George Floyd’s murder was appalling & the MN perpetrators need to be brought to justice, but this cannot be used as a pretext for violence in our communities. 

I thank local leaders for their efforts to keep FL safe.
name: Ron DeSantis

text: Jerad Lindsey’s calling in life was to protect others. He protected Tulsans during his 15 years as a police officer, and he protected his fellow officers through his service in leadership roles with the Tulsa Fraternal Order of Police as well as at the state and national levels.
name: Kevin Stitt

text: Throughout the confirmation process, Judge Barrett has proven her character, professionalism and legal expertise. I look forward to seeing her serve our country and faithfully uphold the rule of law as the newest Supreme Court justice.
name: Kevin Stitt
Kevin Stitt

text:
Welcome home, Officer Zarkeshan!
I’m grateful for your recovery and for all those in law enforcement who are on the frontlines of keeping our communities safe. You live out the #OklahomaStandard and our state thanks you.
name: Kevin Stitt

text: May our nation remain united in the common goal of pursuing freedom, justice, and opportunity for all. To all my fellow Oklahomans, I wish you a happy #4thofJuly
name: Kevin Stitt

text:
I ask Oklahomans to join 
@OKFirstLady
 and me in praying for the officers who were injured, their families and the Tulsa Police Department.

This senseless attack is a reminder of the dangers our law enforcement officers face daily.
name: Kevin Stitt
Kevin Stitt

text:
Tonight at 6 PM we will be taking a moment to listen & learn from leaders in our state's African American community.

Join us as we discuss racism in Oklahoma, law enforcement & how Oklahomans can engage in being part of the solution.
name: Kevin Stitt

text: Let’s demonstrate the Oklahoma Standard by listening to those who are hurting, by uniting to see change that delivers a better future for all, and by being respectful of each other, our police and our first responders.
name: Kevin Stitt

text: Also know this is different from acting out in a way that is violent and damaging property- the State will also support local law enforcement who are respectfully working to stop criminal activity.
name: Kevin Stitt

text: Oklahomans stand together for justice. Like many of you, I am thankful the Minneapolis police officer is being held accountable for the senseless death of George Floyd.
name: Kevin Stitt

text:
This #PoliceWeek we honor our law enforcement officers who faithfully serve and protect their fellow Oklahomans and we remember the fallen heroes who made the ultimate sacrifice while working in the line of duty. 

We cannot thank you enough for your commitment and bravery.
name: Kevin Stitt

text: BREAKING: Judge upholds murder charges against Derek Chauvin and other officers. Important step toward justice for George Floyd.
name: Tim Walz

text:
Minneapolis-St. Paul will *not* have a curfew tonight. 

Our State Patrol and National Guard remain ready to support local law enforcement to keep our neighborhoods and businesses safe tonight.
name: Tim Walz
Tim Walz

text: Let this strengthen our resolve to continue our fight for police reform and accountability until no person has to fear for their lives in the presence of law enforcement due to the color of their skin.
name: Tim Walz

text: Last night, Jacob Blake – an unarmed Black man and a father – was shot multiple times in the back by police. Gwen and I pray for him as he fights for his life, and for his children who witnessed this horrifying event.
name: Tim Walz

text:
100 years ago, the ratification of the #19thAmendment brought us one step closer to a more just and equitable world.
 
Today we are reminded that fairness, justice and equality do not come for free, and that we must continue this fight. Our work is not done.
name: Tim Walz

text:
@LtGovFlanagan
 brings strength and compassion to this work each and every day. I am incredibly proud of my good friend and partner in justice.
name: Tim Walz
Tim Walz
Tim Walz

text: Everyone deserves to feel safe and protected by police. I look forward to signing these long-overdue reforms to strengthen transparency and community oversight, ban chokeholds and warrior training, expand de-escalation training for officers, and reduce the use of deadly force.
name: Tim Walz

text:
George Floyd’s death brought the urgent need for meaningful police reform into sharp focus.

Last night, the #mnleg passed bipartisan police accountability and reform measures. This is a critical step toward justice.

But this is only the beginning. The work does not end today.
name: Tim Walz

text: I'm asking the Legislature to work together on the urgent matters Minnesotans expect them to tackle this summer. We need Republicans and Democrats to rise to the occasion, pass meaningful police reform, fund local jobs and projects, and help Minnesotans rebuild and recover.
name: Tim Walz

text: Philando Castile was killed by a police officer 4 years ago. I’ve been honored to get to know his mother, Valerie, who has channeled her grief into action. Nothing brings the urgency of police reform to light more than a mother’s pain in losing her son.
name: Tim Walz
Tim Walz
Tim Walz

text:
Minnesotans have been loud and clear: It’s time for meaningful police accountability and reform. We've waited and debated long enough.

We need action and we need it now. That’s why I am working with the 
@DFLPOCIcaucus
 to advance their comprehensive reform package.
name: Tim Walz

text:
Today we commemorate a second Independence Day. June 19, 1865 brought freedom and justice for enslaved Black people in Texas, two years after the Emancipation Proclamation. 

We should honor #Juneteenth as a State holiday, and I am working with the #mnleg to ensure we do.
name: Tim Walz

text: Today the Minnesota House will act on police reform that would deliver real changes to our broken system. These ideas are grounded in months of research and conversations with community.
name: Tim Walz
Tim Walz

text: The People of Color and Indigenous (POCI) caucus put together a package of 21 bills that will bring greater police accountability. Their ideas capture the change Minnesotans are asking for, and they must be heard by the Senate.
name: Tim Walz

text:
This is not the time for smaller and slower reform. 

The clock is ticking 
 

Minnesotans want to see police accountability now.
name: Tim Walz

text: To truly be One Minnesota, we need to dismantle the systems of oppression that led to the deaths of Clayton, Jackson, and McGhie 100 years ago, and that led to the death of George Floyd just 3 weeks ago. Today I met with Duluth leaders to discuss how we can and will move forward.
name: Tim Walz

text: Minnesotans are asking us to think bigger. We need to meet this moment, not by half measures or checking a box, but with meaningful reform and police accountability.
name: Tim Walz

text: Karin Housley is a Minnesota Senate Assistant Majority Leader. Tell her Minnesotans have waited long enough for action on police reform.
name: Tim Walz

text: Paul Gazelka is the Senate Majority Leader. He decides which bills reach the Senate floor. Tell him not to block police reform and accountability.
name: Tim Walz

text: Today, 100 years after Max Mason was wrongfully convicted, I granted him a pardon. It’s critical that we take time to grapple with our state’s history of racism.
name: Tim Walz
Tim Walz
Tim Walz

text: In honor of the funeral for George Floyd, we ask all Minnesotans to spend 8 minutes and 46 seconds in silence at 11am this morning.
name: Tim Walz

text: Tom was a giant. As a voice for the voiceless, a passionate pursuer of justice, a loving husband, and a wise and good-humored father, he made a generational impact on our state. I'm forever grateful for his friendship, his counsel, and his family’s contributions to Minnesota.
name: Tim Walz

text:
LIVE: We're responding to 
@AGEllison
 charging all four officers involved in George Floyd's death, and providing an update on public safety concerns. Tune in here: 

http://facebook.com/pg/MPRnews/posts/?ref=page_internal…
name: Tim Walz

text:
The charges announced by Attorney General Keith Ellison today are a meaningful step toward justice for George Floyd.

But we must also recognize that the anguish driving protests around the world is about more than one tragic incident.
name: Tim Walz

text: What will our young people learn about this moment? Will his death be just another blip in a textbook? Or will it go down in history as when our country turned toward justice and change? It’s on each of us to determine that answer.
name: Tim Walz

text: I laid flowers at George Floyd’s memorial this morning. As a former high school history teacher, I looked up at the mural of George’s face painted above and I reflected on what his death will mean for future generations.
name: Tim Walz

text: My administration will use every tool at our disposal to deconstruct generations of systemic racism in Minnesota. This effort is one of many steps to come in our effort to restore trust with communities that have been unseen and unheard for far too long.
name: Tim Walz

text: We’re providing an update on next steps in the state’s response to George Floyd’s death at 2:00pm. You can tune in on your local media station.
name: Tim Walz
Tim Walz

text: The curfew on Friday and Saturday night allowed our law enforcement to target those who meant to do harm to our communities. Law enforcement made several arrests and seized weapons, narcotics, long guns, handguns, magazines and knives.
name: Tim Walz

text: Many Minnesotans are peacefully demonstrating today, and we fully support you. But please know there are people looking to undermine this movement for justice by inciting violence. Please go home by 8pm so that we can remove the people who wish to do our communities harm.
name: Tim Walz

text: The Minnesota National Guard, State Patrol, and local police are on the ground responding to incidents in Mpls-St. Paul. I urge residents to comply with 8pm curfew and go home immediately. Law enforcement needs to respond to emergencies, restore order, and keep Minnesotans safe.
name: Tim Walz

text:
As George Floyd’s family has said, he "would not want people to get hurt. He lived his life protecting people." Let’s come together to rebuild, remember, and seek justice for George Floyd. 

As Governor, I will always defend the right to protest.
name: Tim Walz

text: It is time to rebuild. Rebuild the city, rebuild our justice system, and rebuild the relationship between law enforcement and those they’re charged to protect. George Floyd’s death should lead to justice and systemic change, not more death and destruction.
name: Tim Walz

text: That’s why I’m pushing for a full, fair, and expeditious investigation that will bring us closer to justice. We must continue to examine and address the systemic inequities and discrimination that led to this incident and far too many that have come before.
name: Tim Walz

text: As Valerie Castile told me: Seek justice, seek fairness, and reach out to others. Show each other kindness. The world is watching Minnesota right now. We need to answer by saying and demonstrating peacefully that we will make change together.
name: Tim Walz

text: Our state watched George Floyd’s humanity get erased. Our feelings of anger, anguish, and disillusionment are justified.
name: Tim Walz

text: The lack of humanity in this disturbing video is sickening. We will get answers and seek justice.
name: Tim Walz
Gretchen Whitmer

text: Today, President Trump threatened to send federal law enforcement into many cities, including Detroit. Frankly, he doesn't know the first thing about Detroit. If he did, he’d know Detroiters gathered to peacefully protest the systemic racism that Black Americans face every day.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text:
Today, we marched.

For George.
For Ahmaud.
For Breonna.

I will never be able to fully understand the pain that Black and Brown communities are forced to bear, but I will spend my life fighting for the justice and peace that everyone deserves.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text: Today, I requested that the Michigan Commission of Law Enforcement Standards provide guidance to law enforcement agencies on continuing education, including diversity and implicit bias training, and urging law enforcement agencies to implement duty to intervene polices.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text: [THREAD] The deaths of George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, and Breonna Taylor were a result of hundreds of years of inequity and institutional racism. I am horrified, heartbroken, and taking action
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text:
To those who have taken to the streets to peacefully protest the structural inequities Black Americans face every day - I’m with you.

Tonight, I urge you to stay home and stay safe. Tomorrow, find a peaceful protest to join and make your voice heard.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text: This is a moment that calls for empathy, humanity, and unity. We must remember our enemy is racial injustice, not one another. It’s time for all of us to pull together and do the hard work of building a nation that works for everyone.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text:
Then, I joined a call with my fellow governors and the current president. 

President Trump told governors to ‘put it down’ or we would be ‘overridden.’ He said governors should ‘dominate’ protesters, ‘or you’ll look like a bunch of jerks.’
 
We MUST reject this way of thinking.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text: Yesterday, Michigan Sheriff Chris Swanson set an example for law enforcement across the nation. I’m grateful for his leadership, and hope to see many more follow his lead.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text: People in communities of color across the nation and right here in Michigan are feeling a sense of exhaustion and desperation. We stand in solidarity with those who are seeking equitable justice for everyone in our state. Full statement below
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text: We have to hold those who are perpetuating these abhorrent actions accountable, and in the case of George Floyd, that means charging all four officers who were involved. As governor, injustice and unequal treatment under the law will not be tolerated in our state.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text: As Americans, we have to stand up for what’s right. The killing of George Floyd, and the deaths of people like Ahmaud Arbery, Trayvon Martin and Renisha McBride are not isolated incidents. They are victims of a systemic cycle of injustice in our country.
name: Gretchen Whitmer

text:
Four brilliant constitutional conservative justices making history on the Texas Supreme Court. 

Yesterday I administered the Oath of Office to the newest member—Rebeca Huddle (on the right).

These justices apply the law as written rather than imposing their own agenda.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Today I was joined in Houston by leaders of the Texas Senate & House to sign the #BackTheBlue pledge.

We will pass laws that support law enforcement & defund cities that defund police. 

We will keep communities safe.

#txlege
name: Greg Abbott

text:
21 people from Texas & Louisiana were arrested in Beaumont for human trafficking.

Texas has some of the toughest laws in America that crack down on human trafficking.

We thank local law enforcement for taking action needed to #EndHumanTrafficking.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Texas is providing almost $300 million for Public Safety Initiatives across the state.

This includes funding to crack down on gangs & human trafficking & it funds border security efforts and bullet proof resistant vests for police.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Republicans support law enforcement officers who put their lives on the line every day.

We need them to keep our communities safe.

Democrats want to defund & “reimagine” policing. 

That leads to chaos and mayhem like in Portland & Seattle.

We won’t let that happen in Texas.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Law enforcement officers put their lives on the line every day to keep our communities safe.

This tragic loss is a grave reminder of the dangers they face.

Please lift up their families in prayer.

And remember to #BackTheBlue
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Mobs are rioting in streets, destroying businesses & harming residents.

And YET, Democrats are defunding police.

We need to support our police.

And we must elect Republican Judges who will enforce the law & get tough on criminals.

https://youtu.be/dZ0EzhgYYcA via 
@YouTube
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Austin Police Chief's report shows robberies in Austin increased over the past year. Other violent crimes increased in that time too: aggravated assaults were up 18% & murders were up 40%.

Austin is wrong to defund police.

Texas will take action.

http://kvue.com/article/news/crime/ut-student-robbed-increase-robberies-west-campus/269-9a865d7d-d7ed-4dd8-b5e6-ef10b2a123c9…
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Dallas homicides are on track to surpass last year's record-breaking rate. 

And yet Dallas has cut police over time that is needed to deal with violent crime like this. 

My reforms will prevent cities from defunding police. 

We need to #BackTheBlue.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Austin Police Association says understaffing causes 911 calls to go hours without a response.

This is caused by Austin's cuts to police funding & it endangers lives in Austin.

The State must consider laws that take over policing parts of Austin.
name: Greg Abbott

text: Always great to visit with our brave law enforcement officers. #BackTheBlue
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Property crime rising in Austin.

This is the kind of thing that happens when cities defund and deemphasize police.

Residents are left to fend for themselves.

My plan puts an end to this by requiring cities to fund law enforcement.

#BackTheBlue
name: Greg Abbott

text:
This is good governing:  

Mesquite will cut property taxes, and with smart budgeting they will have funds to hire MORE police officers. 

Thanks Mesquite, Texas, for being such a good example.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Texas is cracking down on rioting.

The Constitution permits "peaceable" protests -- but it doesn't provide the right to riot, rob, loot, set fires or physically harm anyone or any property.

We propose 6 laws that punish rioters & protect communities.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
One of the 10 Most Wanted Fugitives in Texas was captured. 

He is reportedly affiliated with the Bloods gang and was wanted for aggravated robbery and aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. 

Thanks to law enforcement for this arrest.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
I applaud San Antonio for passing a budget that boosts police spending rather than cutting law enforcement spending like some other cities. 

Having well-trained law enforcement is essential to safe communities.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Experts: Proposed state takeover of Austin police legal, but unprecedented.

Well, these are unprecedented times with cities disrespecting & defunding law enforcement.

We will do what is necessary to keep the Capital City safe.

#BackTheBlue
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Join Texans who are signing the #TexasBacksTheBlue pledge.

Show America that we won’t allow Texas cities to defund police.

That would invite crime & mayhem like we’ve seen in LA, Portland, Seattle &  NY. 

Get the pledge at http://gregabbott.com
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Some want to defund our police — but we can’t allow it. 

I’m calling on every Texan & every candidate for public office to join me in signing a pledge AGAINST defunding police tomorrow at 2 PM CT.

Download the pledge at http://gregabbott.com/backtheblue & share using #TexasBacksTheBlue
name: Greg Abbott

text:
This is the right approach:

Dallas mayor opposes cuts to police overtime.

Instead he wants to defund City Hall bureaucracy.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
This proposal for the state to takeover the Austin Police Department is one strategy I'm looking at. 

We can't let Austin's defunding & disrespect for law enforcement to endanger the public & invite chaos like in Portland and Seattle.

#BackTheBlue
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Any defunding of law enforcement must start at the top.

Any mayor or governor that supports defunding police should lose their security detail.

As Austin reshapes police, will Mayor Adler's security detail be a casualty?
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Remarks by President Trump August 31, 2020 about importance of law enforcement to reduce chaos in cities:

"I spent a lot of time in Texas. And I was with the Governor of Texas, Greg Abbott. He was explaining they wouldn’t put up with it for a minute."
name: Greg Abbott

text:
It appears to be open season for Gangs, Organized Crime, and Drunk Drivers in Austin.

Austin's defund police budget took an ax to these units.

Texas won't take it.

If we have to, the state will take over law and order in Austin.
name: Greg Abbott
Greg Abbott

text:
A teacher in a Texas public school comparing police officers to the KKK is beyond unacceptable. 

It’s the opposite of what must be taught. 

The teacher should be fired. 

I’m asking the Texas Education Agency to investigate and take action.
name: Greg Abbott

text:
Texas will defund cities that try to defund their police.

text: The massive and non-violent protests led by Black Lives Matter activists have inspired the nation. Let’s get to work and make this vision a reality.
name: Kate Brown

text: I think we’ve had enough political grandstanding from DC. The President’s plan to "dominate" the streets of American cities has failed. And today, federal troops are preparing to leave downtown Portland. We will protect free speech and the right to protest peacefully.
name: Kate Brown

text:
As federal troops prepare to go home, we have an opportunity to make real and lasting change, centering racial justice and taking bold steps to achieve the vision of the Black Lives Matter movement. 

Let’s get to work.
name: Kate Brown

text: Our local Oregon State Police officers will be downtown to protect Oregonians' right to free speech and keep the peace. Let's center the Black Lives Matter movement's demands for racial justice and police accountability. It's time for bold action to reform police practices.
name: Kate Brown

text: We need to take real and concrete action to reform police training. For law enforcement to have the respect and support of all Oregonians, it is important that police officer training and certification be credible and transparent. https://bit.ly/2CzcrjT
name: Kate Brown

text: This is a democracy, not a dictatorship. We cannot have secret police abducting people in unmarked vehicles. I can’t believe I have to say that to the President of the United States.
name: Kate Brown

text: We lost a legend tonight. Congressman John Lewis exuded justice and equality for all. He was the heart & soul of the civil rights movement. In times of darkness, he reminded us to get into that good trouble and carry on the fight.  Now more than ever, we carry his fight with us.
name: Kate Brown

text:
This, coming from the same President who used tear gas to clear out peaceful protesters in Washington, DC to engineer a photo opportunity.

Trump is looking for a confrontation in Oregon in the hopes of winning political points in Ohio or Iowa.
name: Kate Brown

text: I told Acting Secretary Wolf that the federal government should remove all federal officers from our streets. His response showed me he is on a mission to provoke confrontation for political purposes. He is putting both Oregonians and local law enforcement officers in harm’s way.
name: Kate Brown

text: Today I'm announcing my Public Safety Training and Standards Task Force to fully review law enforcement training, certification, and decertification practices. Thanks to its members for stepping up to this call, and I look forward to reviewing their recommendations.
name: Kate Brown

text: Bold action on racial justice and criminal justice reform is long overdue. But words aren’t enough; We need action. That's why I called a special session and signed into law the legislative agenda of the People of Color Caucus. This is an important step, with more to come.
name: Kate Brown

text: The 56th anniversary of the landmark Civil Rights Act is a time to look back at how far America has come – and to fully commit ourselves to the immense work we still must do in the fight for equity and racial justice.
name: Kate Brown

text: On #JUNETEENTH2020, we mark the anniversary of the day in 1865 when the last enslaved Black Americans in the U.S. were declared free. And we recommit ourselves to keep fighting for change until Oregon – and all of these United States – reflect racial justice.
name: Kate Brown

text: I’m officially proclaiming June 19 as Juneteenth in Oregon and I will introduce a bill in 2021 to make it a state holiday. Celebrating Black freedom this year is fiercely important as people around the world protest systemic racism and undeniably show that Black Lives Matter.
name: Kate Brown

text: During #PrideMonth, I'm remembering the trans women of color at Stonewall who kickstarted so much progress on LGBTQ rights. In our quest for justice & equality, we've made big strides – but we still have so far to go. We can't rest until *everyone* is safe, included, and valued.
name: Kate Brown

text: This should have been Breonna Taylor’s 27th birthday. But instead of celebrating, we're mourning that her life was taken 84 days ago by police officers. Today, we remember, we #SayHerName – and we work for racial justice so it never happens again.
name: Kate Brown

text: We must commit to fundamental change. Words are not enough. We need collective action for racial justice. Here is a list of resources to sustain the momentum of this moment and harness this energy toward making true progress.
name: Kate Brown

text: Today we lower Oregon flags to half-staff across the state in honor of George Floyd. As we mourn his death, let us remember the many Black lives that have been taken by unnecessary violence. And let us commit ourselves, and our country, to fundamental change.
name: Kate Brown

text: The killing of George Floyd is a stain on this country. A single senseless death is one too many. To everyone who is hurting right now, I hear you. I stand with you. And I add my voice to yours.
name: Kate Brown

text: Yesterday thousands of Oregonians mourned and spoke out for justice together. But late last night small groups decided to smash windows and light fires. Senseless violence does not honor George Floyd’s death or create accountability. Only the hard work of racial justice will.
name: Kate Brown

text:
George Floyd. 
Breonna Taylor.
Ahmaud Arbery.
Philando Castile.
Alton Sterling.
 
Too many Black lives taken by racist violence. Far too many. Mourning their loss is not enough. We must commit ourselves to racial justice.
name: Kate Brown

text: I stand with Oregon's communities of color in outrage and anguish over racism and violence, which opposes the fundamental duty of law enforcement to protect and serve. I honor the memory of George Floyd. Together, we will continue to fight for a more just Oregon, and America.
name: Kate Brown
